facts.text: Appeal is Criminal Appeal No. 56 of 1960 in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal NO. 56 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Patna High Court judgment dated November 27, 1959 in Criminal Appeal No. 63 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 27, 1959 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 63 of 1957.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on October 4, 1963 by Das Gupta J.

anchor.surface_text: October 4, 1963. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAs GUPTA J.-

facts.text: Seven appellants tried by Assistant Sessions Judge, Saran, under sections 395 and 323 IPC and acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: These seven appellants were tried by the Assistant Sessions Judge, Saran, on charges under s. 395 of the Indian Penal Code and also under s. 323 of the Indian Penal Code but were acquitted by him of both the charges.

facts.text: On November 15, 1956, Bhadai Sah was passing along village road to purchase patua.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case was that on November 15, 1956 when Bhadai Sah, a businessman belonging to Teotith, within police station, Baikunthpur, was passing along the village road on his way to purchase patua,

facts.text: Seven appellants armed with lathis surrounded Bhadai Sah and demanded money.

anchor.surface_text: the seven appellants armed with lathis surrounded him and demanded that he should hand over the monies he had with him.

facts.text: Bhadai Sah had Rs. 250 with him but refused to part with it.

anchor.surface_text: Bhadai had Rs. 250 with him but he refused to part with them.

facts.text: Kesho Singh tried to take currency notes forcibly from Bhadai Sah's pocket.

anchor.surface_text: Kesho Singh one of the appellants tried to take away forcibly the currency numberes from his pocket but Bhadai caught hold of his arm and raised an alarm.

facts.text: Appellants assaulted Bhadai Sah with lathis after he raised alarm.

anchor.surface_text: On this all the appellants assaulted him with their lathis and as he fell injured Kesho Singh took away the money from his pocket.

facts.text: Kesho Singh took away the money from Bhadai Sah's pocket.

anchor.surface_text: and as he fell injured Kesho Singh took away the money from his pocket. Bhadai thereupon filed a petition of companyplaint

facts.text: Bhadai Sah filed complaint petition in Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Gopalgunj on November 22, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Bhadai thereupon filed a petition of companyplaint in the Court of the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Gopalgunj, on November 22, 1956.

facts.text: Magistrate examined Bhadai Sah on solemn affirmation and ordered Sub-Inspector Baikunthpur to institute case and report by December 12, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate after examining him on solemn affirmation made an order asking the Sub-Inspector of police, Baikunthpur, to institute a case and report by December 12, 1956.

facts.text: Police submitted charge-sheet and accused committed to Sessions Court.

anchor.surface_text: Ultimately, a charge-sheet was submitted by the Police and the accused persons were companymitted to the Court of Sessions.

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted all appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions trial ended, as already stated, in the acquittal of all the appellants.

facts.text: Bhadai Sah filed appeal under s.417(3) CrPC in Patna High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order of acquittal, Bhadai Sah filed an appeal under s. 417 3  of the Code of Criminal Procedure in the High Court of Judicature at Patna.

facts.text: Two High Court judges ordered the appeal to be heard.

anchor.surface_text: On the Following day two learned Judges of the High Court made the order The appeal will be heard.

facts.text: Two other High Court judges set aside acquittal, convicted appellants under s.395 IPC to 2 years RI.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal then came up for hearing before two other learned Judges of the Court who being of opinion that the learned Sessions Judge had rejected the prosecution evidence on unsound standards without any real effort to assess the credibility of the evidence and that the prosecution case was Fully established by the evidence, set aside the order of acquittal and companyvicted the appellants under s. 395 of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced them to two years rigorous imprisonment.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order of the High Court the present appeal has been filed by special leave of this Court.

facts.text: Appellants contended no appeal lay to High Court under s.417(3) as case instituted on police report not complaint.

anchor.surface_text: The main companytention urged in support of the appeal is that in this case numberappeal lay to the High Court against an order of acquittal under s. 417 3  of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

facts.text: Sub-Inspector submitted report on December 13, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: or on the report of the Sub-Inspector of Police dated the 13th December, 1956.

facts.text: Magistrate examined complainant under s.200 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: In the case before us the Magistrate after receipt of Bhadai Sahs companyplaint proceeded to examine him under s. 200 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

facts.text: Court held Magistrate took cognizance on complaint under s.200.

anchor.surface_text: This examination by the Magistrate under s. 200 of the Code of Criminal Procedure puts it beyond doubt that the Magistrate did take companynizance of the offences mentioned in the companyplaint.

facts.text: Magistrate's order was under s.202 CrPC for investigation.

anchor.surface_text: We find that in the case before us the Magistrate after companypleting the examination under s. 200 of the Code of Criminal Procedure and recording the substance of it made the order in these words -- Examined the companyplaint on s.a.

facts.text: Case instituted on Bhadai Sah's complaint on November 22, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: There is thus numberescape from the companyclusion that the case was instituted on Bhadai Sahs companyplaint on November 22, 1956 and number on the police report submitted later toy the Police Sub-Inspector, Baikun- thpur.

facts.text: High Court correctly interfered with acquittal order.

anchor.surface_text: It is quite clear that the High Court examined the matter fully and carefully and on a detailed companysideration of the evidence came to the companyclusion that assessment of the evidence had resulted in a serious failure of justice.

issues.text: Whether an appeal lay to the High Court against the order of acquittal under s.417(3) of the Code of Criminal Procedure, given that the case was allegedly instituted on a police report rather than a complaint?

anchor.surface_text: Against this order of the High Court the present appeal has been filed by special leave of this Court. The main contention urged in support of the appeal is that in this case no appeal lay to the High Court against an order of acquittal under s. 417 3  of the Code of Criminal Procedure. This provision in s. 417 was introduced

issues.text: Whether the case was instituted upon a complaint or upon a police report, determining the applicability of the right to appeal under s.417(3) CrPC?

anchor.surface_text: in the Code by the Amending Act XXVI of 1955, giving a complainant a right of appeal against acquittal where a case is instituted upon a complaint. ... There is thus no escape from the conclusion that the case was instituted on Bhadai Sahs complaint on November 22, 1956 and not on the police report submitted later

issues.text: Whether the High Court was justified in interfering with the order of acquittal passed by the Sessions Judge?

anchor.surface_text: The next contention raised on behalf of the appellants is that the High Court was not justified in interfering with the order of acquittal passed by the learned Assistant Sessions Judge. The reasoning on which the learned Assistant Sessions Judge rejected the evidence of the prosecution witnesses ... the High Court examined the matter fully and carefully and on a detailed consideration of the evidence came to the conclusion

issues.text: Whether the Magistrate acted without jurisdiction in directing the police to institute a case and report?

arguments.claim: No appeal lay to the High Court against the order of acquittal under s.417(3) CrPC because the case was instituted on a police report, not a complaint.

anchor.surface_text: The main contention urged in support of the appeal is that in this case noappeal lay to the High Court against an order of acquittal under s. 417 3  of the Code of Criminal Procedure. This provision in s. 417 was introduced

arguments.court_reasoning: Cognizance taken on complaint via s.200 examination on Nov 22, 1956; police report was under s.202 post-cognizance.

arguments.claim: The High Court was not justified in interfering with the order of acquittal passed by the Assistant Sessions Judge.

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court fully examined evidence, found Sessions Judge's assessment resulted in serious failure of justice, correctly followed Supreme Court principles on acquittal interference.

arguments.claim: The Magistrate acted without jurisdiction in directing the police to institute a case, rendering subsequent proceedings void.
arguments.court_reasoning: Order properly and reasonably read as under s.202 CrPC; at most irregularity not causing failure of justice.

arguments.claim: The Sessions Judge rejected prosecution evidence on unsound standards without assessing credibility; prosecution case fully established; acquittal set aside and convict under s.395 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal then came up for hearing before two other learned Judges of the Court who being of opinion that the learned Sessions Judge had rejected the prosecution evidence on unsound standards without any real effort to assess the credibility of the evidence

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court examined matter fully; assessment resulted in serious failure of justice; principles followed correctly; Supreme Court satisfied on evidence review.

arguments.claim: A case is instituted in court only when the court takes cognizance of the offence alleged therein.

anchor.surface_text: The Code does not contain any definition of the words institution of a case. It is clear however and indeed not disputed, that a case can be said to be instituted in a Court only when the Court takes cognizance of the offence alleged therein.

arguments.claim: Magistrate took cognizance of offences on the complaint upon examining complainant under s.200 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: In the case before us the Magistrate after receipt of Bhadai Sahs complaint proceeded to examine him under s. 200 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. This examination by the Magistrate under s. 200 of the Code of Criminal Procedure puts it beyond doubt

arguments.claim: Magistrate's order directing Sub-Inspector to institute case and report was under s.202 CrPC, not s.156(3), as cognizance already taken.

anchor.surface_text: We find that in the case before us the Magistrate after completing the examination under s. 200 of the Code of Criminal Procedure and recording the substance of it made the order in these words -- Examined the complaint on s.a. The offence is cognizable one.

arguments.claim: Cognizance taken when Magistrate applies mind under Chapter XVI (e.g., s.200 exam), not for s.156(3) investigation; confirmed by precedents R. Chari v. State of U.P. and Gopal Das v. State of Assam.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled not that when on a petition of complaint being filed before him a Magistrate applies his mind for proceeding under the various provisions of Chapter XVI of the Code of Criminal Procedure, he must be held to have taken cognizance of the offences

arguments.claim: Police report under s.173 treated as report under s.202 when case instituted on complaint.

anchor.surface_text: In the view we have taken of the order passed by the Magistrate on November 22, 1956, the report made by the police officer though purporting to be a report under s. 173 of the Code of Criminal Procedure should be treated in law to be a report only under s. 202

holdings.text: The case was instituted on Bhadai Sah's complaint on November 22, 1956 and not on the police report submitted later by the Police Sub-Inspector, Baikunthpur.

anchor.surface_text: There is thus numberescape from the companyclusion that the case was instituted on Bhadai Sahs companyplaint on November 22, 1956 and number on the police report submitted later toy the Police Sub-Inspector, Baikun- thpur.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Magistrate examined complainant under s.200 CrPC after receiving complaint, taking cognizance; subsequent police order under s.202 post-cognizance; s.156(3) pre-cognizance only; precedents R. Chari v. State of U.P. and Gopal Das v. State of Assam followed.

holdings.text: The contention that no appeal lay under s.417(3) CrPC must be rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention that the appeal did number lie under s. 417 3  of the Code of Criminal Procedure must therefore be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Since case instituted on complaint, s.417(3) right to appeal against acquittal available to complainant.

holdings.text: High Court was justified in interfering with the acquittal order as Sessions Judge's assessment resulted in serious failure of justice and principles on interference correctly followed.

anchor.surface_text: It is quite clear that the High Court examined the matter fully and carefully and on a detailed companysideration of the evidence came to the companyclusion that assessment of the evidence had resulted in a serious failure of justice. The principles laid down by this Court

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court fully reviewed evidence, found Sessions Judge rejected prosecution evidence on unsound standards without credibility assessment; Supreme Court principles on acquittal interference followed; Supreme Court satisfied on evidence review.

holdings.text: Magistrate's order asking police to institute case and report properly read as under s.202 CrPC; did not act without jurisdiction; at most irregularity not causing failure of justice.

anchor.surface_text: As we have already pointed out, the order of the Magistrate asking the police to institute a case and to send a report should properly and reasonably be read as one made under s. 202 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. So, the argument that the learned Magistrate acted without jurisdiction cannot be accepted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post s.200 cognizance, only s.202 available for police investigation, not s.156(3); words 'institute a case' reasonably under s.202; no failure of justice.

holdings.text: Police report purporting under s.173 treated as report under s.202 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: In the view we have taken of the order passed by the Magistrate on November 22, 1956, the report made by the police officer though purporting to be a report under s. 173 of the Code of Criminal Procedure should be treated in law to be a report only under s. 202

holdings.reasoning_summary: Given cognizance already taken on complaint, police action follows s.202 inquiry.

holdings.text: A case is instituted when the court takes cognizance of the offence.

anchor.surface_text: The Code does number companytain any definition of the words institution of a case. It is clear however and indeed number disputed, that a case can be said to be instituted in a companyrt only when the companyrt takes companynizance of the offence alleged therein.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed principle; cognizance under s.190 modes determines institution on complaint or police report.

holdings.text: The order of conviction and sentence passed by the High Court cannot be reversed or altered on account of that irregularity.

anchor.surface_text: There is absolutely numberreason, however, to think that irregularity has resulted in any failure justice. The order of companyviction and sentence passed by the High Court cannot be reversed or altered on account of that irregularity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Any irregularity in Magistrate's phrasing did not cause failure of justice.

precedents.citation: R. Chari v. State of U. P. 1

anchor.surface_text: R. Chari v. State of U. P. 1  and again in Gopal Das v. State of, Assam 2

precedents.case_name: R. Chari v. State of U.P.
precedents.cited_proposition: when on a petition of complaint being filed before him a Magistrate applies his mind for proceeding under the various provisions of Chapter XVI of the Code of Criminal Procedure, he must be held to have taken cognizance of the offences mentioned in the complaint. When however he applies his mind not for such purpose but for purposes of ordering investigation under s. 156(3) or issues a search warrant for the purpose of investigation he cannot be said to have taken cognizance of any offence

precedents.citation: Gopal Das v. State of, Assam 2

anchor.surface_text: and again in Gopal Das v. State of, Assam 2  In the case before us the Magistrate after receipt of Bhadai Sahs companyplaint proceeded to examine him under s. 200 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

precedents.case_name: Gopal Das v. State of Assam
precedents.cited_proposition: when on a petition of complaint being filed before him a Magistrate applies his mind for proceeding under the various provisions of Chapter XVI of the Code of Criminal Procedure, he must be held to have taken cognizance of the offences mentioned in the complaint. When however he applies his mind not for such purpose but for purposes of ordering investigation under s. 156(3) or issues a search warrant for the purpose of investigation he cannot be said to have taken cognizance of any offence

anchor.surface_text: The order of companyviction and sentence passed by the High Court cannot be reversed or altered on account of that irregularity.
